titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of Athletics Programs at New York University RG.41
titlestmt.author: Claire Wolford. Additional processing by Elizabeth Alleva.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-20 17:54:32 -0400.

did.unittitle: Records of Athletics Programs at New York University

physdesc.extent: in 75 manuscript boxes, 165 record cartons, 23 flat boxes, 1 card box, 1 cassette box, and 1 flat file folder

did.abstract: This collection contains the records of the New York University Athletics Department, including materials related to intercollegiate and intramural teams, player information, newspaper clippings, press releases, photographs, and team rosters and schedules. The collection spans from approximately 1889 to the 2010s.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Administrative records and unpublished reports of New York University are closed for a period of 20 years from the date of their creation. Access to files spanning multiple years will be opened to researchers based on the date of the most recent materials. Board of Trustees records are closed for 35 years from the date of creation. Materials related to personnel, grievances, job and fellowship searches and applications, and all files that fall under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) are permanently restricted. Additional restrictions may apply to other materials in this collection. For questions regarding specific restrictions, please contact the University Archives.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred to the archives in numerous accessions between 2012-2018. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 12.03, 2019.033, 2018.022, 06.029, 15.043, 2016.004, 2016.042, 16.016, 92.033, and 2020.034.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Duplicate pieces of the Bobcat Costume were deaccessioned in February 2019.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized by sport, with additional series designated for administrative records, promotional material and records related to NYU athletes who competed in the Olympics.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Athletic competition began at New York University in 1873, when the first intercollegiate games in baseball and football were played. Formal intercollegiate competition did not begin until 1894, when NYU's move to the University Heights campus in the Bronx provided space for a budding athletics program to grow. On that campus the University erected a new gymnasium, as well as football and baseball fields. By 1907 the University fielded varsity baseball, football, basketball, tennis, and track teams.

NYU athletics continued to grow in success and popularity throughout the first half of the 20th century as sports became co-ed. Women's sports such as swimming, tennis and baseball began as informal "co-ed activities" in the 1920s and later became varsity programs. The University also saw a number of its students, coaches, and alumni participate in the Olympics, including Sam Jones, Howard and Ted Cann, Jose and Miguel De Capriles, Byron Dyce, and Carol Heiss.

The University's financial struggles forced the Athletics department to shut down both football and basketball in the 1970s as NYU left its Bronx campus. Athletics at NYU experienced a resurgence in the 1980s with the construction of the Jerome S. Coles Sports Center and the move from Division I to Division III competition. The basketball team was reactivated in 1983 and continues to play. NYU currently has varsity teams in basketball, cross country, fencing, golf, soccer, swimming and diving, tennis, track and field, volleyball and wrestling. Baseball returned as a varsity sport in 2015 and softball was added as a result of NYU's completed merger with NYU-Poly.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Records of the Athletic Department; RG 41; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions regarding arrangement, description, and physical interventions for this collection prior to 2019 are unknown. Duplicate pieces of the Bobcat Costume were deaccessioned in February 2019. In June 2019 memorabilia was rehoused by preservation and sent offsite. In September 2019 wrestling student-athlete registration cards (1985-1986) underwent basic mold cleaning.

In 2020, Boxes 223, 224, and 225 were inspected by Preservation staff for mold; items in these boxes showing no evidence of mold were removed from their original boxes and moved to Box 269. Materials with evidence of mold were sent to Polygon for cleaning in early 2020 and returned in September 2020. During this process, Box 227 was deleted and the single folder of material from this box was transferred to Box 225.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The University Archives Photo Collection contains images of NYU teams and players from the late 19th century into the 1980s. Late 19th and early 20th century athletics images can also be found in the Historic Photographs and Drawings Collection (PHOTO 002).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection is comprised of the records of athletics programs at New York University. It spans from 1889 to the 2000s and includes newspaper clippings, press releases, team statistics, rosters, schedules, program and player information related to a number of team and individual sports. The frequency of each type of record varies from series to series.
The bulk of the collection relates to basketball, football and baseball.
Additionally, RG 41.9 is not listed but is reserved for records pertaining to the University Athletic Association.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the creator are maintained by New York University. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from New York University Archives, 212-998-2646, university-archives@nyu.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series touches on a wide array of subjects within NYU athletics. It includes sports and athletics program schedules, clippnigs, correspondence, and records relating to NYU Hall of Fame inductees Esther V. Foley and Albert B. Nixon. There are also copies of the athletics sections of The Violet, The Album, and the School of Education Violet yearbooks as well as records relating to the University Athletic Association and copies of "The Violet Line: The Official Newsletter of New York University Athletics".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ID Number: 148. Description: The Violet, flower costume.

did.unittitle: Navy blue blazer with patch and two faded purple sweaters with NYU logo

bioghist.head: History of Basketball at NYU
bioghist.p: Basketball has long presence at NYU. It began as an intra-school sport in 1897, only six years after the game was invented by Dr. James Naismith. Varsity competition began in 1906. The team, led by a student captain, won six of eight games the first year. Two years later the NYU Violets recorded their first undefeated season, winning all 13 games played. During the 1919-1920 season, the Violets achieved a 16-1 record and took part in the National Championship Tournament in Atlanta, where they won four straight games and became the National and World Champions. Howard Cann, who would go on to coach at NYU for 35 seasons, was voted the best player at that tournament. NYU teams would later practice in a gym on the University Heights campus made of two joined barns and nicknamed Cann's Barn.

A decade later the Violets were playing at Madison Square Garden. Among the early stars of the team were All-American Hagan Anderson, Milt Schulman, Jerry Fleishman, Sid Tanenbaum, Don Forman, Dolph Schayes, Cal Ramsey, Tom "Satch" Sanders, Mal Graham, Barry Kramer, and Boris Nachamkin. These athletes led NYU into the NCAA Division I Championships five times between 1919 and 1960. The Violets were popular among the students, alumni, and the community, and the games were big sellers at Madison Square Garden.

By the 1970s, the University was in a dire financial situation and cut the basketball program in an effort to balance the its budget. Following a gradual improvement in the school's financial standing, NYU reintroduced basketball in 1983 in Division III competition under Coach Mike Muzio.

Women's basketball dates back to 1923. It was initially considered a "co-ed activity" until the 1930s, when it became a varsity sport. The University has had several winning teams since that time. Today the women's basketball team is one of the top teams at NYU and won the Division III Championship in 1997 with Coach Janice Quinn and players Marsha Harris and Jen Krolikowski.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.1 includes newspaper clippings, basketball season schedules, photographs, tournament information, specific game and player breakdowns, official scorer's reports, pre-season rosters, coaches notes, player statistics, collected clippings, press information sheets, alumni basketball event correspondence, rosters, game souvenirs, season programs, brochures, tickets, retrospectives, and player biographies.
Men's basketball results for 1906-2013 can be found in Archives H. Women's basketball results for 1923-2014 can be found in Archives H.

did.unittitle: Alumni Cocktail Parties with Basketball Trips
Comments About Former NYU Basketball Players
NYU Women's Basketball National Champions pennant

bioghist.head: History of Baseball at NYU
bioghist.p: NYU's baseball program was established in the 1870s as something akin to a club sport. The move to the University Heights campus in 1894, with its expansive athletic facilities and fields, allowed the NYU baseball team to become a legitimate intercollegiate competitor. The team was not very successful in its early years, however, with the varsity team losing all but one of 13 games in 1902.

The team did experience a resurgence in the 1920s under coach William McCarthy. Between 1922 and 1961, he led the NYU Violets to 476 victories and 258 losses. Among the outstanding players of the 1920s was George "Kiddo" Davis, the first NYU baseball starter to break into the major leagues. In 1927, Davis signed with the New York Yankees, and six years later the Yankees won the World Series. Numerous other baseball alumni would go on to play in the major leagues.
By the early 1970s the University's financial situation was critical, and radical changes to the overall budget were necessary. The University Heights campus was sold, and the baseball team was cut. With the loss of the Bronx campus there was no space to practice or play home games. Baseball was reinstated in 1996 as a club sport. It joined the NCBA and played in Division II, District II alongside Hofstra University, Cabrini College, and Rider University.
Varsity baseball returned to NYU in spring 2015 as a Division III sport when NYU-Poly, which had its own team, officially became part of NYU.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 2 includes early baseball tickets, schedules, and programs, as well as a scrapbook created for the 1902 baseball season. Beginning in 1941 and continuing until 1972 there are folders organized by year with an assortment of baseball schedules, player and team statistics, newspaper clippings, and NYU press releases. There are also a number of player biographies.

bioghist.head: History of Fencing at NYU
bioghist.p: Fencing became a varsity sport in 1923. The NYU fencing team has attracted talented athletes and has regularly sent students and alumni to compete in the Olympics. From the late 1950s to the 1970s the men's fencing team was one of the best in the nation, earning 12 national titles between 1947 and 1976. The women's team has also been very successful, winning national championships 10 times. Both teams continue to compete in NCAA Division I. Twenty-eight NYU fencers competed at the Olympics between 1928-1984. Of these 28, one competed for Finland, one for Italy, and the rest for the United States.
Men's fencing results for 1927-2014 can be found in Archives H. Women's fencing results for 1928-2014 can be found in Archives H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3 is comprised of materials generated between 1925 and 1995 related to fencing team activities at New York University. Papers include fencing team schedules, press releases concerning players and the teams, team rosters, game and championship programs, as well as player biographies.

bioghist.head: History of Football at NYU
bioghist.p: The NYU football team was founded in 1873. It was one of the first university-sponsored teams in the U.S., preceded only by Princeton, Rutgers, and Yale. During its inaugural season, NYU lost its only game, to the Stevens Institute of Technology, which was also a brand new team.

Few documents from NYU football's early years have survived, but existing records indicate few wins early on. Following the acquisition of the University Heights campus in 1894, the team began playing and practicing on Ohio Field.

NYU was integral to the regulation of college athletics in the early 20th century, helping to found the Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States, precursor to the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA).

The late 1920s became known as the "Golden Era" of NYU football. The school played a number of games at the new Yankee Stadium, and coach John Meehan led the team to 49 wins and only 15 losses. When Meehan left in 1931, the team was unable to continue its earlier successes, in part because World War II drained the player pool and financial resources.

After the war, the team tried to recapture its previous popularity and success, but increased funds did not lead to increasing interest or ticket sales. In 1953 the team was disbanded. Football made a short return in 1964 as a club sport but never caught on and was officially discontinued in 1967 because of lack of interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a number of player biographies, including newspaper clippings and NYU press information on specific players, team rosters and schedules, statistics, game programs, and NYU press releases concerning the team. These materials range in date from 1889 until 1967.

bioghist.head: History of Gymnastics at NYU
bioghist.p: Gymnastics makes a brief appearance in the history of athletics at NYU. It was first practiced in 1894 after the addition of the University Heights campus in the Bronx. In March of 1897 the Athletic Association held the first dual gymnastic meet for prizes. There, NYU defeated Lehigh University. Two years later NYU hosted its first intercollegiate gymnastics event with 19 other colleges. Events included the horizontal bar, tumbling, club swinging, fence vaulting, rings, parallel bars, high jump, and the side horse. World War I interfered with the burgeoning team's growth, and the team was disbanded in 1919.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of New York University gymnastics meet programs and tickets ranging from 1898 to 1906.

bioghist.head: History of Track and Field at NYU
bioghist.p: The earliest mention of New York University's track and field team is in the University Heights 1896 Violet yearbook. Since then, NYU has aided in the training of many track and field Olympians. The earliest track meets were held outside at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus, which was constructed in 1900. In 1912, the New York University Track Association held its first annual indoor meet at the 22nd Regiment Armory. In 1971 coach Joe Healey was named the United States Track Coaches Association Coach of the Year.
Today men's and women's track and field teams continue to compete at the varsity level in the University Athletic Association Conference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Track and Field Series contains track event programs, statistics, and newspaper clippings as well as player biographies. Track sports began at NYU in 1895, and this series has records dating back to 1899 and continuing somewhat sporadically through 2007.
Men's and women's track and field results for 2003-2014 are located in Archives H. Men's and women's cross country results for 2000-2014 are located in Archives H.

did.unittitle: Track and Field Statistics and Clippings
Cross Country, Indoor, & Outdoor Track and Field

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a correspondence file of Director of Athletics Dan Quilty. Quilty served in this position from 1972-1996. The file represents several years of communication with Vice President for Student Affairs Jane Maggin.

bioghist.head: History of Coles Sports Center
bioghist.p: The Coles Sports Center, located at 181 Mercer Street, was opened in 1981 and named after NYU alumnus and benefactor Jerome S. Coles. The new facilities provided the University, which had recently returned entirely to its downtown campus, with a location for sporting events, team practices, health and wellness activities, and community recreation. The Coles Sports Center served as the home for NYU's NCAA Division III teams and also hosted a number of events including NCAA Men's and Women's National and Regional Championships in basketball and fencing as well as international wrestling and fencing competitions.
In 2014, NYU announced plans to demolish Coles and build a new facility in its place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of Coles Sports & Recreation Center Information Booklets and Program Guides ranging from 1981 to 2010 and arranged chronologically.

bioghist.head: History of Olympic Athletes at NYU
bioghist.p: NYU athletes have been competing in the Olympics since 1904. Between that year and 1988, 19 athletes from NYU have won a total of 28 medals.
Fencing and track have generated the most Olympians from NYU. In 1988 an exhibition was created to highlight the successes of NYU's Olympic athletes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of materials relating to the NYU Olympic athletes from 1904-1988, including rosters and biographies of these athletes as well as material from a 1988 exhibition on NYU athletes who have competed in the Olympics.

bioghist.head: History of Tennis at NYU
bioghist.p: Men's tennis gained varsity status in 1907 and the first squad consisted only of four players. From the 1919 to 1927 seasons the men competed without a coach. During the 1930s the men's team consistently made the New York State Intercollegiate Championships. Men's tennis is strictly a spring sport.
Women's tennis started at NYU in the late 1920s. The team played only in the spring until 1973, when they added fall competition.
Men's and women's tennis teams continue to compete at the Division III level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.11 contains the records pertaining to the tennis team. Men's tennis began at NYU in 1907, and women's tennis began in 1923. The records within this series range from 1919-1976 and contain tennis records, rosters, schedules, press releases, and clippings.
Men's and women's tennis results for 1983-2014 are located in Archives H.

bioghist.head: History of Golf at NYU
bioghist.p: Golf became a varsity sport at NYU in 1930. Just nine years later, however, the team was dissolved. When it returned in 1954, the men went undefeated with victories over city rivals Manhattan College, St. John's University, and Columbia University. In the 1980s, the team used Riverdale Country Club in New Jersey for its home matches. The team competes at the Division III level in the University Athletic Association conference.
Women's golf arrived at NYU in 2007.
Men's golf results for 2000-2014 can be found in Archives H. Women's golf results for 2007-2014 can be found in Archives H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The golf team was started at New York University in 1930. The records for this team span 1930 to 1976 and contain player biographies, newspaper clippings, golf tournament programs, and NYU press releases.

did.unittitle: Golf Press Information and Team Records

bioghist.head: History of Soccer at NYU
bioghist.p: Soccer arrived at NYU in 1923 and was called "soccer football." The 1923 team had a winning season despite a lack of funds and a field on which to practice. In 1926, the program was terminated but returned in 1958 in an informal capacity. The team went undefeated in its first year back under the leadership of Coach Allan Towbin. Soccer returned to varsity status in 1959. The NYU soccer team continues to compete on the varsity level for both men and women in the University Athletics Association Conference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the soccer team, including newspaper clippings, press information, team rosters, and player biographies ranging in date from 1958 to 1973. There is also some documentation from the initial iteration of the team in the 1920s.
Men's soccer results for 1983-2014 can be found in Archives H. Women's soccer results for 1995-2014 can be found in Archives H.

did.unittitle: Soccer Team Rosters, Press Information, and Clippings
Soccer Team Rosters, Press Information, and Clippings
Soccer Clippings, Press Information, and Awards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Cross-Country Team

bioghist.head: History of Swimming at NYU
bioghist.p: Men's and women's swimming became varsity sports in the 1920s. Swim meets were held at the University Heights campus until its closure in 1973. When the Coles Sport Center was completed in 1981, the teams had a new home near Washington Square. Both teams have had numerous winning seasons throughout the years and have produced a number of Olympians. The men's and women's swimming teams continue to compete at the Division III level of the NCAA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Swim Team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Diving Team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Volleyball Team.

bioghist.head: History of Wrestling at NYU
bioghist.p: Wrestling became a varsity sport at NYU in 1934 under the direction of Olympian Charles Cranford. Interest declined the following season and the wrestling program went on hiatus until 1939. In the 1970s the NYU wrestlers topped the Metropolitan and Eastern rankings. The wrestling team competes today at the Division III level of the NCAA. They are a member of the University Athletic Association (UAA) Conference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Wrestling Team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Softball Team.

bioghist.head: History of Bowling at NYU
bioghist.p: NYU briefly had an all-female bowling team that competed during the 1940s and 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Bowling Team.

bioghist.head: History of Riflery at NYU
bioghist.p: Riflery was brought back to NYU in 1929 after having been dissolved years earlier. The team practiced at ranges on the University Heights campus and had great successes during the 1930s. In 1931 the freshmen team was named the national intercollegiate champion. Riflery is no longer a competitive sport at NYU.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Riflery Team.

bioghist.head: History of Field Hockey at NYU
bioghist.p: The NYU field hockey team played its first games in the 1924 season. This varsity team practiced at Central Park and Prospect Park. In 1931 the team played a game on the Ohio Field at University Heights, becoming the first female team to play on this field. Field hockey is no longer a competitive sport at NYU.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 41.13 is comprised of the records of the Field Hockey Team.
